Case 6-5 _
Brought to the ER after a Suicide Attempt
Max Perrin, a 55-year-old male, was brought to the emergency room (ER) by
the local rescue squad following a suicide attempt by means of consuming
rat poison. The ER physician, Dr. Christopher LeMarke, recognized him im-
mediately, as did the ER nurses. He had been a regular in the facility,
having visited for his primary medical care and for two previous suicide
attempts within the past eighteen months. During the previous visits his
history had been explored completely. He was divorced, alienated from his
adult children, and chronically depressed but was not considered suffi-
ciently impaired that he could be declared incompetent.
On the basis of state law, such patients could be held for up to seventy-
two hours on the signature of two physicians if they were deemed danger-
ous to themselves or others. Mr. Perrin had never before engaged in any
behavior that would suggest he was dangerous to others, but he surely was
a danger to himself. He had on past admissions received short-term psy-
chotherapy and prescriptions for antidepressant drugs, but he had stopped
taking them because he said they made him feel sleepy.
He was now in the ER, incoherent and semiconscious. Should Dr. LeMarke
sign the involuntary commitment, enlist another physician to sign as well,
and initiate another round of therapy?

data.vignette: A 55-year-old man is brought to the ED after ingesting rat poison in a suicide attempt. He is a familiar patient with chronic depression and two prior attempts. After initial stabilization he becomes awake and oriented. He says he regrets coming, refuses inpatient psychiatry, and asks to leave as soon as his labs allow. He acknowledges the ingestion was intentional but insists he can “handle it” and will not return for follow-up. He has previously stopped antidepressants because of sedation and distrusts psychiatric care. The team is divided about whether his hopelessness and recent attempt make his decision unreliable despite his apparent understanding. Medical clearance is expected within hours, and the disposition decision must be made before discharge. State law and hospital policy permit either discharge or a short emergency psychiatric hold in this situation.
data.choice_2: Discharge him after medical clearance with outpatient referrals

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the minimum additional clinically-relevant details needed to evaluate decisional capacity and imminent self-harm risk (e.g., brief mental status exam, whether he currently endorses suicidal intent/plan, whether ingestion was impulsive vs planned, access to lethal means, availability of reliable supports). Clarify what “medical clearance” entails for this ingestion (e.g., toxicology confirms no expected delayed life-threatening effects after observation/antidote), so discharge is medically coherent. Remove or tighten vague phrasing like “as soon as his labs allow” to a concrete clinical threshold (e.g., ‘after X hours of observation and repeat coagulation studies are stable’).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Strengthen the legal defensibility of *both* options by adding a sentence that the jurisdiction allows an emergency hold when a patient is deemed an imminent danger to self, but does not require it if—after evaluation—the patient is judged to have decision-making capacity and no imminent intent. Add brief facts that could plausibly support discharge without being reckless (e.g., he denies current suicidal intent, agrees to a safety plan, has a responsible adult who can stay with him, and accepts a scheduled follow-up within 24–72 hours), while keeping hold defensible if the clinician judges imminent risk despite these assurances.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Rebalance the vignette so discharge is not obviously wrong. Currently he ‘regrets coming,’ refuses inpatient care, says he won’t follow up, and has hopelessness + prior attempts—this makes an involuntary hold the clear choice. To make the dilemma genuinely hard, add countervailing factors favoring discharge (e.g., he now states the attempt was impulsive, denies current intent or plan, demonstrates coherent reasoning and understanding of consequences, is willing to remove/lock up lethal means, and has reliable supports/transport). Also explicitly include meaningful downsides of an involuntary hold (e.g., prior traumatic hold experience, credible risk of job loss/childcare disruption, worsened distrust leading to disengagement from care), so both options carry real moral cost.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so discharge is ethically defensible, not obviously unsafe after a recent suicide attempt. Add concrete facts that reduce (but do not eliminate) imminent self-harm concern—e.g., he now denies current suicidal intent, expresses future-oriented plans, accepts means-restriction at home, agrees to a same/next-day urgent psychiatry appointment, and a reliable family member can provide supervision and confirm access to medications/poisons is removed. Simultaneously, make the costs of an involuntary hold more ethically weighty—e.g., he has a history of traumatic prior holds, will likely lose employment/housing or custody if detained, and the unit is overcapacity leading to prolonged ED boarding with restraints/sedation risk. Keep uncertainty about decision-making capacity (not clearly impaired or clearly intact) so reasonable clinicians could defend either option.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize subtly judgmental/framing phrases. For example, change “He is a familiar patient” to “He has a documented history of major depressive disorder with two prior self-harm presentations.” Replace “regrets coming” with “states he no longer wishes to remain in hospital.” Avoid implying the conclusion by changing “make his decision unreliable” to “raise concern about whether he has decision-making capacity for discharge.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Replace colloquial/non-clinical wording with medical terminology. Change “rat poison” to “anticoagulant rodenticide ingestion (e.g., long-acting superwarfarin).” Specify clinically standard elements briefly (e.g., toxicology consultation, monitoring for coagulopathy/bleeding) without adding probabilities. Keep the tone as ED/consult documentation.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to only facts that drive the ethical dilemma and forcing context. Remove redundancies (e.g., combine refusal statements) and cut nonessential backstory (“familiar patient”). Consider a clearer capacity snapshot: state he can paraphrase risks/alternatives and articulate a consistent choice, while clinicians note persistent hopelessness. Keep the forcing mechanism as “medically cleared within hours; disposition decision required now.”

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce explicit self-harm/trigger phrasing while preserving clinical meaning. Replace “suicide attempt” with “intentional self-poisoning” or “self-harm behavior,” and avoid vivid wording. Keep description clinical (e.g., “ingested an anticoagulant rodenticide in a self-harm act”). Avoid detailed method descriptors beyond what is necessary for care context.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Revise choices to neutral 10–15 word action statements without embedded rationale. Example:
- Choice 1: “Place the patient on a 72-hour involuntary psychiatric hold for evaluation.”
- Choice 2: “Discharge after medical clearance with a documented safety plan and urgent outpatient follow-up.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the vignette so discharge is not framed as clearly reckless and hold is not framed as clearly safer. Edits: (1) Add protective factors supporting discharge: e.g., patient has a supportive spouse/partner present who can monitor, agrees to remove lethal means, accepts a same-day safety plan and agrees to return if worsening; expresses specific reasons for living. (2) Add ethically meaningful harms/costs of a hold beyond inconvenience: e.g., patient is primary caregiver or at risk of losing housing/job; prior traumatic experience with restraints; concern that coercion will rupture therapeutic alliance and reduce future help-seeking. (3) Add concerns/costs of discharge beyond suicide risk to avoid one-sidedness: e.g., limited outpatient access, uncertain reliability of family supervision, or inability to ensure means restriction. (4) Remove/soften loaded language that implies incapacity (e.g., “will not return for follow-up”) or add nuance (e.g., he refuses inpatient but is willing to attend an urgent outpatient visit).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, a realistic third option exists: discharge with a structured safety plan plus rapid follow-up/partial hospitalization, involve family, arrange crisis team, or extend ED observation for reassessment. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule these out: e.g., ‘No crisis stabilization/partial program beds are available today; next outpatient psychiatry appointment is weeks away; family cannot be reached or declines involvement; ED cannot keep him longer due to bed constraints; patient refuses any safety planning or lethal-means counseling.’ Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 to include the best-available discharge package (means restriction counseling, confirmed next-day appointment, warm handoff), and Choice 1 as hold—then make clear those are the only two disposition pathways allowed by policy.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Suicidal ingestion with recent attempt commonly triggers statutory criteria for emergency detention; many institutional protocols treat a recent suicide attempt + stated intent/not engaging in safety planning as grounds for involuntary hold. The line ‘policy permit either discharge or a short emergency psychiatric hold’ is not enough to neutralize this. Fix by: (1) Specify why criteria are genuinely ambiguous: e.g., he now denies current suicidal intent, shows organized thinking, and is assessed by psychiatry as having decision-making capacity but with persistent risk; or the ingestion was low-lethality/uncertain exposure with no ongoing tox risk. (2) Clarify that psychiatry consult is split or that local law uses a higher threshold (imminent risk) and he does not clearly meet it, yet risk remains concerning. (3) Avoid suggesting a blanket permission; instead state that both dispositions are legally permissible depending on clinician judgment of ‘imminence’ and capacity in this specific presentation.

data.vignette: A 55-year-old man is evaluated in the ED after intentional self-poisoning with an anticoagulant rodenticide. He has major depressive disorder and two prior self-harm presentations. After observation with toxicology input, his exam is stable and repeat coagulation studies remain normal; no delayed life-threatening effects are expected if he returns for repeat labs. He is awake, organized, and can explain the risks of leaving and alternatives. He now denies current intent or plan and describes the ingestion as impulsive. His spouse is at the bedside and agrees to monitor him, secure medications and poisons, and bring him back if symptoms or thoughts worsen. He also reports a prior involuntary admission that involved restraints and says another hold could cost him his job and disrupt caregiving for his mother. However, the spouse works nights, outpatient psychiatry cannot see him for several weeks, and you cannot confirm means restriction at home. Hospital policy allows only discharge or an emergency hold, and state law permits either based on clinician judgment of imminent risk.
data.choice_1: Place him on a 72-hour involuntary psychiatric hold for evaluation.
data.choice_2: Discharge after medical clearance with a safety plan and urgent follow-up arranged.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the patient explicitly requests discharge (and/or refuses voluntary admission) after demonstrating decision-making capacity.

To justify Choice 1 as clearly beneficent, add one clause indicating imminent suicide risk despite denial (e.g., continued intent, access to lethal means at home, or inability to contract for safety). To justify Choice 2 as clearly violating beneficence, add one clause that safety planning/follow-up is unreliable (e.g., spouse cannot reliably supervise and he declines/has no timely follow-up or refuses to return for repeat labs).

Add an explicit justice/system-level tradeoff (e.g., “the inpatient psych unit is at capacity and a hold would board him in the ED and potentially displace another high-risk patient” or, alternatively, “recent audits show involuntary holds are applied disproportionately to patients with similar presentations”).

data.vignette: A 55-year-old man is evaluated in the ED after intentional self-poisoning with an anticoagulant rodenticide. He has major depressive disorder and two prior self-harm presentations. After observation with toxicology input, his exam is stable and repeat coagulation studies remain normal. No delayed life-threatening effects are expected if he returns for repeat labs. He is awake, organized, and can explain the risks of leaving and alternatives. He requests discharge and refuses voluntary psychiatric admission. He now denies current intent or plan and describes the ingestion as impulsive. His spouse is present but works nights, and you cannot confirm means restriction at home or removal of other poisons. Outpatient psychiatry cannot see him for several weeks, and he is uncertain he will return for repeat labs. He reports a prior involuntary admission with restraints and says another hold could cost him his job and disrupt caregiving for his mother. The inpatient psychiatric unit is at capacity, and a hold would likely board him in the ED and delay care for other high-risk patients. Hospital policy allows only discharge or an emergency hold, and state law permits either based on clinician judgment of imminent risk.

choice_2.choice: Discharge after medical clearance with a safety plan and urgent follow-up arranged.

human_evaluation.comments: this case would revolve around a suicide risk assessment. the autonomy concerns are problematic because what the patient wants may be colored by the recent suicide attempt. but there could be judgment calls. I think worth seeing how it plays out ... there will be disagreement i suspect.
